Description: Help to get started with Azure DevOps services.
Learn how to use Azure Repos to manage code source.

Acceptance Criteria: A new repository Web App is created in Azure Repos.
Description: As a developer, I would like to create a new repository for my web application, so I can manage the code with Azure Repos.

• Go to Project Settings
  • Go to Repositories
  • Click +Create button
  • Give Repository name, like Web App
  • Uncheck 'Add a README'
  • Click Create

1. Go to Repos
  2. Click Branches
  3. Click 'Import' button under Import a repository
  4. Enter https://github.com/shiyinbai/WebAppDemo.git under Clone URL
  5. Click Import

Title 3: 1.2 - Cloning repository and working with Visual Studio Code
Acceptance Criteria:
• Clone the repository on local machine
  • Work with VS Code
  • Push changes to Azure Repos
Description: As a developer, I would like to clone the repository on my local machine, so I can work with VS Code.

Title 4: 1.2.1 - Clone repository in Visual Studio Code
Description:
1. Navigate to Repos
  2. Click Clone
  3. Click Clone in VS Code button under IDE

1. Go to Program.cs file in VS Code.
  2. Add some comments on the top of the file, like // My first change.
  3. Save change and commit it
  4. Synchronize changes

1. Switch to Azure DevOps
  2. Go to Repos
  3. Click Commits
  4. Check the changes on the file Program.cs with comments 'My first change'

Acceptance Criteria:
• Create a new branch on local machine
  • Push new branch to Azure DevOps
Description: As a developer, I would like to create a new branch, so I can work independently and avoid to impact other developers.

Title 4: 1.3.1 - Create dev branch from VS Code
Description:
1. Go to VS Code
  2. Open command palette with shortcut: Ctrl+Shift+P
  3. Enter Git: Create Branch From...
  4. Enter new branch name dev
  5. Select the master as reference branch

Title 4: 1.3.2 - Working on dev branch and publish to Azure DevOps
Description:
• In VS Code, make sure you are working on dev branch
  • Open Program.cs file, on the top of file, change // My first change. to // My second change.
  • Commit changes
  • Publish branch
  • Check dev branch has been created in Azure DevOps Repos

Acceptance Criteria:
• Define branch policies
  • Push to main branch only by using a pull request
Description: As a Developer, I would like configure branch policies, so I can protect the main branch by pull request.

1. Go to Azure DevOps
  2. Click Branches of Repos hub
  3. Find the message you updated dev xxm ago
  4. Click Create a pull request button
  5. In New pull request form:
    1. Verify that the pull request merge changes from dev to master
    2. Enter Title and Description
    3. Click Create button

1. Go to Pull requests of Repos hub
  2. Click on the pull just created
  3. Complete the pull request
  4. Check the merge result on master branch

1. Go to Azure DevOps
  2. Click Project settings
  3. Click Repositories
  4. Click Web App Demo repository
  5. Click Policies tab
  6. Click master branch at the bottom of the page
  7. In Branch Polices section:
    1. Toggle on Require a minimum number of reviewers and set value to 1
    2. Tick Allow requestors to approve their own changes
    3. Toggle on Check for linked work items
    4. Toggle on Check for comment resolution

Create a pull request
  1. Switch to VS Code
  2. Switch to master branch
  3. Synchronize changes
  4. Create a new branch named pull-request-policies-test from the master branch
  5. Open Program.cs file
  6. On the top of file, change // My second change to // My third change
  7. Save change and commit it
  8. Push branch to Azure DevOps
  9. Switch to Azure DevOps
  10. Go to Pull requests of Repos hub
  11. Click Create a pull request button
  12. Enter Title and Description
  13. Click Create button
Add comment to changes
  1. Go to the pull request just created
  2. Click Files tab and add a comment to the changes like 'This comment needs to be resolved'
  3. Click Comment button
Review required checks
  1. Go back to Overview tab
  2. Noticed that there are 2 required check failed
  3. On the right, click + button for Work items and link to this task
  4. On the bottom of comment section, write a reply like 'resolved' and click Reply&Resolve button
  5. Click Approve button on the top right of the page
  6. Click Complete button
  7. Tick on Complete associated work items after merging
  8. Click Complete merge
Check Task state
  1. Go to  Boards of Boards hub
  2. Go to the user story 1.4 - Working with Pull Request
  3. User the tasks, verify that the stat of task 1.4.4 - Test pull request policies is closed and the reason is Completed
  4. On the right of the task page, notice that the pull request just completed was linked to this task under Development
Learn how to use Azure Pipelines for continuous integration and delivery.

Acceptance Criteria:
• A pipeline is created
  • When running pipeline, resources are deployed
Description: As a DevOps Engineer, I would like to create an infrastructure deployment pipeline to automate Azure Resources deployment.

Go to Project Settings
Go to Pipelines -> Service connections 
Choose Azure Resource Manager in new service connection popup
Select Service principal
Select Subscription as Scope level
Give a Service connection name, like: SC-SIKA-DEVOPS-LABS
Click Save

Go to Pipelines -> Library
Click +Variable group
Give variable group name, like Web App Deploy Configuration
Add variable name Suffix, value xxx (user identity)
Add variable name ServiceConnectionName, value SC-SIKA-DEVOPS-LABS
Click Save

• Go to Pipelines-> Pipelines
  • Click Create Pipeline button
  • Select Azure Repos Git
  • Select Web App Demo repo
  • Select Starter pipeline
  • Replace Starter pipeline with the following YAML: 
trigger: 
 branches:
    include:
      - master
 paths:
    include:
       - deployment

pool:
  vmImage: ubuntu-latest

variables:
- group: Web App Deploy Configuration
- name: deploymentDefaultLocation
  value: westeurope

jobs:
- job:
  steps:
  
  - task: AzureResourceManagerTemplateDeployment@3
    inputs:
      deploymentScope: 'Subscription'
      connectedServiceName: $(ServiceConnectionName)
      deploymentName: $(Build.BuildNumber)
      location: $(deploymentDefaultLocation)
      csmFile: deployment/main.bicep
      overrideParameters: >
        -resourceNameSuffix $(Suffix)
        -location $(deploymentDefaultLocation)
  • Save pipeline with name 'iac-pipeline.yml' and run it
  • Check the following deployed resources on Azure:
    • Resource gpoup: rg-SUFFIX
    • App Service: ase-SUFFIX
    • APP Service plan: plan-SUFFIX

Acceptance Criteria:
• A pipeline is created.
  • When running pipeline, web app project is built and deployed on Azure.
Description: As a developer, I would like to create a pipeline for web app, so the code changes will be automatically built and deployed.

• Go to Pipelines-> Pipelines
  • Click Create Pipeline button
  • Select Azure Repos Git
  • Select Web App Demo repo
  • Select Starter pipeline
  • Replace Starter pipeline with the following YAML: 
trigger:
 branches:
    include:
      - master
 paths:
    include:
       - src
       
parameters:
- name: RestoreBuildProjects
  displayName: Project path
  type: string
  default: '**/src/*.csproj'

variables:
- group: Web App Deploy Configuration
- name:  buildConfiguration
  value: Release
- name: appName
  value: 'ase-$(Suffix)'

steps:
- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  displayName: Restore
  inputs:
    command: restore
    projects: ${{ Parameters.RestoreBuildProjects }}

- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  displayName: Build
  inputs:
    projects: ${{ Parameters.RestoreBuildProjects }}
    arguments: '--configuration $(BuildConfiguration)'

- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  displayName: Publish
  inputs:
    command: publish
    publishWebProjects: True
    arguments: '--configuration $(BuildConfiguration) --output $(build.artifactstagingdirectory)'
    zipAfterPublish: True
    
- task: AzureWebApp@1
  displayName: 'Deploy Web App' 
  inputs:
    azureSubscription: $(ServiceConnectionName)
    appType: webApp
    appName: $(appName)
    package: '$(build.artifactstagingdirectory)/**/*.zip'
  • Save pipeline with name 'wap-pepeline.yml' and run it
  • go to url: https://ase-(SUFFIX).azurewebsites.net

Title 3: 2.3 - Trigger web app pipeline by modifying code source
Acceptance Criteria:
• Pipeline is trigged when code changed
  • Web site is updated
Description: As a developer, I would like the web app pipeline is trigged automatically when code changed, so the web site will be updated accordingly.

Title 4: 2.3.1 - Create a branch to modify web app code source
Description:
1. Go to VS Code
  2. Make sure your are working on master branch
  3. Synchronize changes with remote
  4. Open command palette with shortcut: Ctrl+Shift+P
  5. Enter Git: Create Branch From...
  6. Enter new branch name add-logo
  7. Select the master as reference branch
  8. Go to src\Pages\Shared
  9. Click _Layout.cshtml file
  10. Replace <a class="navbar-brand" asp-area="" asp-page="/Index">WebAppDemo</a> by 
    <img class="navbar-brand" src="data:image/png;base64,"/>
  11. Save file and commit change
  12. Publish branch

1. Go to Azure DevOps
  2. Click Branches of Repos hub
  3. Find the message you updated add-logo xxm ago
  4. Click Create a pull request button
  5. In New pull request form:
    1. Verify that the pull request merge changes from branch add-logo to master
    2. Enter Title and Description
    3. link work item to this task
    4. Click Create button
    5. Approve and complete pull request

• Go to Pipelines
  • Check Web App Deployment pipeline is starting running
  • Click the pipeline and check the deployment details

Title 4: 2.3.4 - Browse website to check the changes
Description:
• Browse to url : https://ase-(SUFFIX).azurewebsites.net
  • Verify that SIKA logo is showing on the top of page
Learn how to share code efficiently by publishing a package in Azure Artifacts.

Acceptance Criteria: • A repository Shared Library created in Azure DevOps
Description: As a developer, I would like to create a repository for shared library, so I can manage the code in Azure Repos.

1. Go to Project Settings
  2. Go to Repositories
  3. Click +Create button
  4. Give Repository name, like 'Shared library'
  5. Uncheck 'Add a README'
  6. Click Create

1. Go to Repos
  2. Click Branches
  3. Click Import button under Import a repository
  4. Enter https://github.com/shiyinbai/ArtifactDemo.git under Clone URL
  5. Click Import

Acceptance Criteria:
• A new project feed created in Azure Artifacts
  • Feed permission for pipeline configured
Description: As a developer, I would like to create a new feed in Azure Artifacts, so I can store and manage packages and control who to share it with.

Go to Azure DevOps
Go to Artifacts
Click + Create Feed button
Enter name SharedLibrary
Keep default value for other parameters
Click Create button

Go to Artifacts
Click Feed Settings button near Recycle Bin on the top right of page
Go to Permissions tab
Set Project Collection Build Service as role Contributor

Acceptance Criteria:
• Create a artifact pipeline
  • Run pipeline and check package is pushed to feed
Description: As a developer, I would like to create a artifact pipeline, so I can publish NuGet package to feed.

• Go to Pipelines-> Pipelines
  • Click Create Pipeline button
  • Select Azure Repos Git
  • Select Web App Demo repo
  • Select Starter pipeline
  • Replace Starter pipeline with the following YAML 
trigger:
 branches:
    include:
      - master
 paths:
    include:
       - StringLibrary

pool:
  vmImage: ubuntu-latest

variables:
  Version: 1.0.0
  buildConfiguration: Release

steps:
- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
  displayName: Build
  inputs:
    projects: '**StringLibrary/*.csproj'
    arguments: '--configuration $(BuildConfiguration)'

- task: NuGetCommand@2
  inputs:
    command: pack
    packagesToPack: '**StringLibrary/*.csproj'
    packDestination: '$(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)'
    configuration: '$(BuildConfiguration)'

- task: NuGetAuthenticate@0
  displayName: 'NuGet Authenticate'
  retryCountOnTaskFailure: 0
  
- task: NuGetCommand@2
  displayName: 'NuGet push'
  inputs:
    command: push
    nuGetFeedType: internal
    versioningScheme: byEnvVar
    versionEnvVar: Version
    publishVstsFeed: 'SIKA DevOps Labs/SharedLibrary'
    allowPackageConflicts: true
  • Save pipeline with name 'lib-pepeline.yml' and run it
  • Go to Artifacts and verify that a new package has been published
